comment.author: 56105315@N07
comment._content: Fascinating image. There's a fair bit of movement from some of the soldiers. Gives it a slightly ghostly feel.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/56105315@N07] Some of them were definitely fidgety and must have driven the photographer mad. Do you mean the chap with the newspaper in the row of chairs on the right? He must have been flying through that paper, leaning forward and back...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Great photograph but there are a number of things about it that raise a question mark.  Why have they all (bar 1) got their caps on indoors in a recreation room?  I've worn uniforms for most of my life and one of the first things one does is take the darned cap off and especially in a room such as this.  They are all, more or less, facing the camera which would indicate that it was posed and if so why did the silly beggars insist on moving so much?  The likelihood that an Irish ampersand is used in a religious text in a British army rec room is remote to say the least.  This was a rec room for other ranks i.e privates as there are no officers present and no signs of ranks on the sleeves of tunics as far as I can see.  As regards "Golden SCA text" I expect that it was something like Services Christian Association?  Very interesting indeed!  Another thought struck me, why all the flowers?  There must have been a generals inspection coming off for this level of adornment?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Definitely agree about the posing! Caps were on for the photographer without a doubt. I have another one from the Curragh tomorrow, and again all are wearing their caps... So do you think 16.7.16 is safe enough to assume as the date??
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I think it is safe enough.  The flowers are "cut-flowers" and are fresh as distinct from pot plants and they are plentiful so that means spring/summer at the least.  July is probably right for that shot!  The ampersand used up to recently in material relating to the Dept. of Posts and Telegraphs did have the 7 shape but it was distinctively lower that the other numbers.

comment.author: 54708393@N08
comment._content: Given the low emulsion speed of the film/glass plate of this period (probably  as low as ISO 10) indoor exposures without flash powder would be several seconds long,so even slight movements would cause blur,if the minute hand on the clock moved during this period it would effectively "disappear".

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Grand. Will add this date then, unless anyone else raises any major objections. Huzzah, another photo dated!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/54708393@N08] Wow, talk about "here comes the science bit"! That's brilliant, and might explain the mystery of the missing hand (if it's missing, and wasn't in fact noon).
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: July 16, 1916 was during the Battle of the Somme, so these poor chaps were probably hearing about the bloody battle going on, and were perhaps a bit nervous about being deployed? The one on the left appears to be reading a newspaper, but you can't zoom in enough to see...

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: In response to Oaktree-brian the vast majority of them are probably reading newspapers or magazines which were placed in cardboard hard covers by the messmen to keep them together and to keep them tidy, I think you're right about that one, it does appear to be a newspaper.  While I was looking at that individual I noticed the apparatus behind him for opening the ventilation in the rooflights!  Quite a complicated little gizmo that takes the turning rods through two fairly severe angles to open and close the window sashes, reminds you how good the engineering was in those days.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66151649@N02] And bear in mind that it was just 2 and a half months since the Easter Rising too! Chap on the left definitely reading a newsaper or a large magazine...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Very similar gizmo in some of the rooms in the old parts of the Library...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Checkers on this side of the pond (Canada), draughts in proper English I suppose :)

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Not a good time in that part of the world to be in the military.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Brian, there are a few subtle differences in the two games!  I was playing checkers recently and was grossly offended to be attacked from behind which was against the rules of draughts!  The answer I got was that we were playing checkers!

comment.author: 77338355@N06
comment._content: This is the Reading Room of Miss Sandes Soldiers Home in the Curragh Camp. Elise Sandes from Tralee, Co Kerry founded this movement near army camps in Ireland, England and India. She was an evangelical missionary and her aim was to provide wholesome recreation for young soldiers to keep them away from pubs. There were over thirty homes at one stage, eight of them in India. Their only rule they said, was "welcome" as on the back wall. The Curragh Home was the headquarters from its foundation in 1911 and incredibly it stayed open until the 1970s, serving the Irish army. Some of the buildings around the country have survived but not the one in the Curragh. Irish soldiers remeber the Home with great affection and appreciation. The movement still survives today, in much reduced form, in Northern Ireland. See www.sandes.org.uk for some history. And article in The Irish Sword of Summer 2007 for more info.

comment.author: 77338355@N06
comment._content: A short acount of Sandes Soldiers Homes is here: www.historyireland.com/volumes/volume13/issue4/news/?id=1...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77338355@N06] I cannot thank you enough for adding this information! So many things make sense now, e.g. the Bible verse, the big WELCOME sign... I read your contribution and the History Ireland article with great interest, especially about the temporary summer presence in camps such as at the Glen of Imaal. We have many old photos of such summer encampments, and I'll certainly be looking at them with fresh eyes to see if there's any evidence of Elise Sandes and her colleagues. Thanks again! Have added your information and links, etc. to the description under the photo...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 78620024@N07
comment._content: I'm sure alot of the tables and chairs in this photo were still in use in the 1960s.What I can remember from that time.A tennis table,one billard table.two maybe three full size snooker tables.You had use of these tables for half an hour, for a fee.There were smaller tables with magazines wrapped in hard folders.With titles like 'Soldier'.'Look And Learn'.'Country Life'.On Fridays (when we had some cash) time would be passed in this room.playing draughts.bagatelle,watching does with more money playing snooker,while eating a bag of chips.Just before 8 PM.we paid our 8 pence and headed into Sandes Picture House.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/78620024@N07] Fantastic information, and sorry I missed it at the time you commented. Delighted to hear about 'Look and Learn' as I've mentioned that to people before (we used to get it at home) and nobody's ever heard of it! What kind of films were shown at the Picture House?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
